```{r}

library(readxl)
library(dplyr)

file_path <- "C:\\Users\\mansi gopani\\Downloads\\Typical_Employee_Survey_Data.xlsx"
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data <- read_excel(file_path)
head(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)


#1. Add Header Row
colnames(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data) <- c("litchi", "grapes", "avacado","watermelon","mango","papaya","berry","melon","banana","apple","kiwi")
print(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)


#2. Print out the 5-point summary and boxplot (numerical columns) for each column
summary(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)

for (i in 1:ncol(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)) {
  boxplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data[[i]], main = paste("Boxplot of Column", colnames(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data[i])), ylab = names(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)[i])

}

#3. Convert the columns that need to be converted to Factors
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$grapes <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$grapes)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$avacado <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$avacado)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$watermelon <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$watermelon)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$papaya <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$papaya)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$berry <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$berry)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$melon <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$melon)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$banana <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$banana)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$apple <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$apple)
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$kiwi <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$kiwi)
print(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)


#4. Plot the right visual for each column
#Plotting Histogram for continuous data
library("ggplot2")

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = litchi)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "yellow", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Histogram - Column litchi")
 
ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = mango)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "yellow", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Histogram - Column mango")
 
# Plotting Bar Plot for Factor data

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = grapes)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column grapes")

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = avacado)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column avacado")

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = watermelon)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column watermelon")
 
ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = papaya)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column papaya")
 
ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = berry)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column berry")
 
ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = melon)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column melon")

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = banana)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column banana")
 
ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = apple)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column apple")

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = kiwi)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  ggtitle("Bar Plot for Column kiwi")


#5. Plot scatter plots to show few relationships

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = litchi, y = grapes)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue") +
  ggtitle("Scatter Plot for Column litchi vs Column grapes") +
  xlab("Column litchi") +
  ylab("Column grapes")

ggplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data, aes(x = litchi, y = avacado)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue") +
  ggtitle("Scatter Plot for Column litchi vs Column avacado") +
  xlab("Column litchi") +
  ylab("Column avacado")
```
